intro: Microchilus peruvianus, commonly known as the Peruvian microchilus, is a small, delicate flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments, such as forest understories or rocky crevices. Its flowers are usually white or pale yellow, and it produces small, dry fruits that disperse its seeds. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
